newsitem.title: USA: Delta sees spring changes aiding performance.
newsitem.headline: Delta sees spring changes aiding performance.

text.p: Delta Air Lines said its spring 1997 schedule changes are expected to improve operating performance and support Delta's long-term strategy to build on its competitive strengths in its major hubs.
With the new schedule, Delta said it will offer 587 daily flights at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport where it already operates the world's largest hub.

Delta's April schedule in Atlanta will feature over 100,000 seats daily with nonstop service to 111 destinations. It said it will add new non-stop service to San Jose and introduce additional flight frequencies in seven other markets, including Baltimore, Cincinnati, Dallas/Fort Worth, Miami, Orange County (CA), Salt Lake City (two new flights) and San Francisco.

At its Cincinnati hub, the airline will add new flight frequencies to Lexington, Nashville and Norfolk. It said the Delta Connection carrier COMAIR will also expand its Cincinnati service as 50-passenger Canadair Regional Jet flights replace Delta's non-stop service between Cincinnati and Harrisburg, Knoxville and Rochester.
The schedule changes will be effective on April 6, 1997, and are available for sale now.

Delta said it will discontinue its single frequency, non-stop flight from Cincinnati to Vancouver. With the changes, it will operate 216 daily departures with non-stop service to 71 destinations at Cincinnati, its second largest hub.

Earlier this year, Delta announced a realignment of its transatlantic route system to strengthen Delta's strategic position across the North Atlantic and New York's JFK gateway. Also earlier this year, Delta announced changes in its Mexico service, including an expansion of the Delta/Aeromexico code share relationship.
